abstract.p: Sampling of Columbus Day events in New York City and New Jersey (M)

block.p: Italian-American communities have historically celebrated Columbus Day with parades and receptions. There are also festivals and exhibitions this month that highlight the culture of the indigeneous people of the Western Hemisphere. Here is a sampling of events:

*The 27th Powhatan Renape Nation semi-annual Indian arts festival, featuring music, dance, art, crafts, oral histories, and foods. Performers include Joanne Shenandoah, a composer and vocalist from the Wolf Clan of the Iroquois Confederacy, Oneida Nation. Rankokus Indian Reservation, Rancocas Road, Westhampton Township, Burlington County, Oct. 7-9, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $10, adults; $5, seniors and children 6-12; free for children 5 and under; (609) 261-4747or www.powhatan.org.

*''Who Stole the Tee Pee?'' an exhibition examining how Indian artists have responded to social, political and cultural change, and featuring more than 40 works by contemporary Indian artists. Oct. 1 through Jan. 21, 2001, admission is free; National Museum of the American Indian, George Gustav Heye Center, One Bowling Green, Manhattan; (212) 514-3804.

*''Mother Love: Native Women and the Land,'' featuring works by Nadema Agard (Lakota/Cherokee), Sally Larson (Aleut), Tara O'Keefe (Santo Domingo), and Laura Ortman (White Mountain Apache), through Dec. 2. American Indian Community House Gallery Museum, 708 Broadway, Manhattan; (212) 598-0100.
*Intercontinental Indigenous Women's Gathering and Reception, Friday, Oct. 13, 9:30 a.m., Mama Mexico Restaurant, 2672 Broadway at 102nd Street, Manhattan; (212) 598-0100.

*The 30th Annual Italian Tribune News Columbus Day Parade. Kicks off at noon at Branch Brook Park, Bloomfield Avenue at Lake Street, Newark, and travels west to Bloomfield Avenue at 15th Street, Bloomfield. Grand marshals are the actor Nicholas Turturro and Lou Lamoriello, president of the New Jersey Devils.

*The Columbus Day Parade of New Jersey, sponsored by the cities of Garfield, Hackensack and Lodi, and Hackensack University Medical Center and Filippo Berio Olive Oil Company Opening ceremonies 11 a.m. at Columbus Park, Memorial Drive and Arnot Street, Lodi, and ending at Dahnert's Lake Park in Garfield.
*Nutley-Belleville Columbus Day Committee Parade, 2:30 p.m. today at Belleville High School, Chestnut Street and Passaic Avenue, ending at Chestnut Street and Franklin Avenue, Nutley.
